prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The IRAM-measured CO global velocity width of 166.2 km/s is larger than the velocity dispersion expected in individual synthetic beams. This source has an expected velocity spread of 20 km/s per beam, which we can readily detect at the chosen sensitivity. Depending on compactness, measuring point-by-point velocity dispersions with a precision as low as 5-10km/s is possible. Spectral averaging has been utilized to hold the data rate down. One spectral window is centered on the CO 2-1 line. Three of the four basebands have been allocated to low-resolution continuum measurements which, together with the continuum available in the CO 2-1 spectral window, will yield 7.5GHz of total continuum bandwidth.

The most compact 12m configuration permits mapping the gas on the required (~kpc) physical scales. The LAS here corresponds to gas spread over the galaxy's optical (Petrosian) diameter.
In this target, the ACA, together with a small, source-centered 5-beam mapping scheme are required to recover, with uniform sensitivity, the expected smooth gas distribution of 19.4".
Though not anticipated, if substantial CO emission were spread over even larger scales (e.g. twice the optical diameter), the spatial filtering of the 12m array would not recover such an extended configuration of low surface brightness emission. This would, however, manifest as a noticeable difference in the globally integrated line intensities compared to our IRAM 30m measurements, from which we could estimate the fraction of truly extended emission.
Source filtering simulations using the SIMALMA package, adopting optical g-band light as a proxy for the CO emission distribution, validate the ACA-based mapping approach (see Fig. 3).

For each object, we divide the total expected integrated CO 2-1 line intensity up among the 1.5" beams of the most compact 12m configuration in Band 6. The 2-1 integrated line intensity is derived by scaling the IRAM 30m CO 1-0 measurement of 0.48 K km/s by a factor of 3 (Leroy et al., 2009), and we have adopted a resolved bandwidth of 20km/s appropriate to CO velocity dispersions on kpc scales in nearby galaxies. The scale of the gas is set to approximately 5x the Spitzer/IRAC 8um diameter, providing detection sensitivity out to ~15kpc.
For the 1.3mm continuum estimate of 0.23 mJy, we adopt the global photometric measurements from WISE, Spitzer, and Herschel, fitting the constructed SED with the dust models of Draine & Li, 2007, and extrapolating to 1.3mm (see Fig. 4). We will integrate over the full 7.5GHz of available bandwidth, and, as necessary, spatially average over all resolution elements to achieve a global 1.3mm continuum measurement, which will increase the estimated continuum detection S/N.
The beam spacing of 0.40 was chosen to be slightly better than Nyquist to ensure a galaxy-centered beam placement, in case the gas extent is more compact.

Though not anticipated, if substantial CO emission were spread over even larger scales (e.g. twice the optical diameter), the spatial filtering of the 12m array would not recover such an extended configuration of low surface brightness emission. For each object, we divide the total expected integrated CO 2-1 line intensity up among the 1.5" beams of the most compact 12m configuration in Band 6. The 2-1 integrated line intensity is derived by scaling the IRAM 30m CO 1-0 measurement of 2.58 K km/s by a factor of 3 (Leroy et al., 2009), and we have adopted a resolved bandwidth of 20km/s appropriate to CO velocity dispersions on kpc scales in nearby galaxies. The beam spacing of 0.40 was chosen to be slightly better than Nyquist to ensure a galaxy-centered beam placement, in case the gas extent is more compact.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
To explain the nature of present day galaxies, contemporary models of galaxy evolution require feedback to expel a substantial fraction of the gas and dust fueling stellar and black hole growth, driving galaxies into quiescence. Post-starburst galaxies are systems found precisely in this phase - shortly after star formation has been abruptly halted - but little is known about the dust and gas content of these systems. We have recently discovered surprisingly large reservoirs of dust and molecular gas in a sample of post-starbursts. Incredibly, they are producing stars at a pace more than 10x below what is expected. A critical question is why this gas is not forming stars in line with the well-studied 'SF law'.
To understand the fate of molecular fuel after quenching, we propose deep CO 2-1 mapping of 8 post-starbursts with well-measured molecular gas and dust masses, sampling a wide range of precisely determined post-burst ages from 0.3-1.5Gyr. Continuum measurements at 1.3mm will also provide powerful contraints on cold dust content. ALMA alone has the sensitivity and resolution needed to probe the state of the dusty molecular fuel left behind in galaxies 'After the Fall.'
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: PI: French Title: 'Dense Molecular Gas in Post-Starburst Galaxies: A New Laboratory for What Stops Star Formation' Project Code: 2015.1.00356.S
